column19: Description
A common stone. Can be knapped into tools.
Hard stone with sharp edges when broken. Ideal for primitive tools.
Calcium-rich stone useful for construction and lime production.
Wet clay that can be shaped and fired into pottery.
Fine granular material for construction.
Lightweight fuel that burns hotter than wood.
A small wooden stick. Useful for handles and kindling.
A section of tree trunk. Must be processed before use.
A flat piece of sawn lumber.
Tree bark. Can be used for cordage or containers.
Long plant fibers suitable for cordage.
Twisted plant fibers forming a simple rope.
Sticky tree resin processed into waterproof adhesive.
Raw meat from a hunted animal. Should be cooked.
Fresh caught fish. Best cooked before eating.
Animal bone. Can be shaped into tools and needles.
Raw animal hide. Needs to be tanned.
Hide with flesh and hair removed. Ready for tanning.
Properly tanned leather. Durable and flexible.
Animal tendon. Strong binding material.
Bird feather for fletching arrows.
Rendered animal fat for cooking and crafting.
A handful of wild berries. Small but nutritious.
A foraged mushroom. Hopefully not poisonous.
Wild onion bulb with a strong flavor.
Oak tree nut. Bitter unless processed.
Starchy cattail root. Can be eaten raw or cooked.
Well-cooked meat. Safe and nutritious.
Grilled fish with crispy skin.
Warm roasted berries. Concentrated flavor.
Simple flatbread cooked in ash.
Untreated water. Risk of illness.
Boiled or filtered water. Safe to drink.
Warm herbal infusion with mild healing properties.
A crude stone axe. Better than nothing.
Sharp flint blade for cutting.
Heavy stone for hammering.
Sharpened bone for sewing hides.
Hardened wooden stick for digging roots.
Friction fire-starting kit.
Properly hafted stone axe. Much more effective.
Curved flint blade for scraping hides.
Stone bowl and grinder for processing food.
Woven basket trap for catching fish.
Simple loop trap for small game.
Folded bark container for carrying items.
Shaped clay pot ready for firing.
Fired clay pot for cooking and storage.
Leather bag for carrying water.
Fire-hardened wooden spear.
Carefully knapped flint spear point.
Spear with flint point. More lethal.
Smooth rock sized for throwing.
Woven sling for hurling stones.
Foraged herbs with healing properties.
Herb-infused dressing for wounds.
Rigid sticks for immobilizing broken bones.
Dry material that catches fire easily.
Small dry sticks for starting fires.
Split wood for sustained burning.
Stick with pitch-soaked head for lighting.
